title: 104_hr748
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Federal Tax Equity Act" exempts residents of the District of Columbia from certain taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Residents of the District of Columbia are exempt from taxation under the District of Columbia Federal Tax Equity Act if they are bona fide residents for the entire taxable year. Additionally, individuals who have been residents for at least 2 years before changing their residence from the District of Columbia are exempt from taxation on income earned during their period of residency in the District of Columbia. An individual in the District of Columbia cannot deduct any deductions or credits against excluded income. Residency status is determined by regulations. Wage withholding is not applicable if the employee is expected to be a bona fide resident for the entire year. The employee must be a bona fide resident of the District of Columbia for the entire calendar year. SEC. 137 and SEC. 138 pertain to residents of the District of Columbia and cross-references to other Acts. The effective date for amendments made by this section is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The limitation on estate and gift taxes includes a new section for residents of the District of Columbia under SEC. 2210. For residents of the District of Columbia, the estate transfer tax is subject to a specific subchapter, treating the decedent as an individual under that subchapter. The gross estate value excludes tangible property within the District of Columbia. Residents of the District of Columbia are treated the same as individuals meeting specific requirements for estate and gift tax purposes. The amendments apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after the enactment date. Additionally, a new section is added to provide a credit for businesses operated in the District of Columbia. The new section provides a credit for businesses in the District of Columbia. The new section allows a District of Columbia business credit based on taxable income from trade or business activities in the district and qualified District of Columbia source investment income. The new section establishes a District of Columbia business credit for taxable income from trade or business activities in the district and qualified District of Columbia source investment income. This credit is part of the general business credit and applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. STUDY OF FEDERAL REVENUES IN DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. The Mayor of the District of Columbia will conduct a study on the effects of amendments on revenues and the impact of Federal revenues on the District, including direct payments, government spending, and income sources. Recommendations for revisions in Federal law may be included in the study. The Mayor of the District of Columbia will conduct a study on the effects of amendments on revenues, including recommendations for revisions in Federal law to increase District revenues. A report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act.
